content.description: Climb up the slab and trend left to the arete below the roof. Pull the roof, working up and right to a stance (physical crux). Move up and left across the steep face and around the arete (technical crux), finally moving up onto a ledge. Top out and find the fixed anchors to your right.
content.location: This section of cliff is about 100 feet left of the other routes at Serac Wall (toward Keene Valley). Find the route 30 feet from the stream below a large roof that is 30 feet up. Start on the slab below the roof.

climbs.name: The Other Side of Insanity
climbs.fa: FFA Ross Manny, Geanette Orton, Andy Johnstone, October 15, 2020

content.description: This is far better than its neighbor. The climbing is awesome; the only detraction is the road noise. It is a beautiful line: sustained, pumpy, and technical. It is well bolted, and would be a safe onsight for a new 5.10 leader.Either stick clip or boulder your way to the small ledge and first bolt. Make your way up and right to the arete. Work your way up the arete as it steepens through a bulge (crux). Topout on a ledge and find the fixed anchors to your right.FA (TR) Geanette Orton, Ross Manny, Andy Johnstone, Jordan Hand, Kristen Castro
content.location: The obvious, tall vertical fin of rock. Begin on the left side below a small ledge 10' up.

content.description: Climb directly up and through a left-facing/blocky dihedral (crux) into a small overhang, followed by a crack system to the top. Climb as an offwidth or by using abundant features outside the crack. Step up to a large birch tree.This route could be easily toproped by ascending the climber's right gully, or used to access the bolted anchor on the fin.
content.location: 15' right of the obvious fin and Edge of Insanity is this crack/chimney line.

climbs.name: Edge of Insanity, aka The Shark's Fin
climbs.fa: FA Pat Purcell, FFA Ross Manny, Geanette Orton 7/6/20

content.description:
This climb is quite unique and very close to the road. It has two distinct cruxes - the roof is physically demanding and there is a technical crux above the first bolt.

 Start up a chossy corner with big holds. Make a few crack moves over a roof to get established on the prominent arete. Up this to the top.
content.protection: Single rack to .75, micro cams helpful, nuts are a must. The gear is good but tricky above the roof!
content.location: The obvious, tall vertical fin of rock

content.description: A relatively forgotten crag which has seen some recent attention, resulting in two standout routes that climb either side of an amazing blade of rock. A trivial approach makes this a perfect option for short sessions along with the Aquarium. When the leaves are up though, you probably wouldn't see it from the road unless you knew it was there!
